newsitem.title: USA: Money managers' US debt allocations steady - survey.
newsitem.headline: Money managers' US debt allocations steady - survey.

text.p: Money managers made few changes to their U.S. debt portfolios in the week ended August 20, said a survey by Stone & McCarthy Research Associates Inc.
"Money managers simply were not involved in the market to any significant degree," the report said. "Those who were involved made only modest changes in portfolio structure."
The report said the survey's bear/bull index arithmetic reading climbed to 4.66 from 4.46 the week before, while the asset-weighted number came in at 4.65, up from the 4.52 of the previous period.
A number above 5.00 is seen as indicating investors are mostly long on the market.
The cash/assets ratio held mostly steady at 6.21.
Duration bogey upticked slightly to 4.06 on an arithmetic basis from 4.05 the week before. On a weighted basis, duration bogey was unchanged at 4.69.
Duration bogey is the level of asset or liability duration sought in the management of a portfolio.
Duration refers to a portfolio's average maturity and is used by portfolio managers to calculate exposure to risk.

Twelve percent of portfolio managers polled said they were planning to be active in the coming week, down from 16 percent the week before. The bear/bull index collected among those who intend to be active rose to 5.67 from 4.88.
The Stone & McCarthy survey is conducted by the research firm weekly. It includes 25 market participants with total assets of about $100 billion, the firm said.
* Table provided by Stone and McCarthy Research Associates.
** Respondents intending to adjust portfolio in coming week.
